children.subject: There are better math graduate courses than 228A if you are into ML; 221 (numerical linear algebra) might be a better choice although it seems like it isn't offered that much. Functional analysis might be helpful when dealing with kernel methods so consider 206 also.

Yeah Lin is teaching 228A next semester. Did you take it? If so, what you think of it?

I need grad classes to do the honor program.

Yes, I took it last fall semester. I am very interested in numerical DE so I like the class very much, but I would say it is not fun (even boring) for most people, especially if you enjoy hardcore mathematics. 228B will be really fun for people in any background by the way. However, if you need an A/A- for the honor program, this class is easier compared to other pure math classes. The best option is to choose the class you are most interested in, the curve for graduate classes is generous~

Ah, I see. Thanks!

How did you find the workload be like? I want to take 202A or 250A, but I have only done 104 and 113 (no 105/14x series/114), thus 228A seems like the one that will be the one I don't have difficulties to understand the materials.

7 problem set only, no exam last fall. I don't know the particular "workload" for you, because it also depends... But if you want the easiest graduate math course, I believe 228A is the best choice, no prerequisite, maybe 128A, but I don't think it is necessary. You will be fine.

If you are interested in probability, I highly recommend 202A+218A. 202A+Fubini is the "hard" prerequisite of 218A, so if you don't know measure theory in advance you need two years to complete these two courses if you have time. But I believe learning probability with measure theory is worth every bit of time from a mathematical and learning standpoint. (I know nothing about machine learning so maybe 126 is more valuable in practice, I took 127 and I believe it is essential for ML) You could take 202A first and see if you like serious math though.

It really depends, somebody could handle four graduate classes and somebody could handle two upper divisions one semester. 206 will be overkill, and 202B is the prereq for 206 I believe (At least you need to know Hilbert space and some basic theorems like Riesz to start 206). 228A is completely unrelated to machine learning, which covers numerical ODE&PDE, but 221 would be a good fit if it is offered next semester. If Prof.Lin teaches 228A next semester he will devote 1/3 of the semester on Krylov subspace and GMRES. If you are interested in math why not start with 202 or 250? By the way why do you need a math graduate class to graduate?

history.content: Will I be okay? I need a math graduate class to graduate, and I'd really want to take both 126 and 127 because I am very interested in math and machine learning.
history.subject: MATH 228A + EE 126 + EE 127 for Fall 2018
